Substituting this into Eq. (7) and noting that ‖𝐖l‖≤1normsubscript𝐖𝑙1\|\mathbf{W}_{l}\|\leq 1 gives us the upper bound in the theorem.

For the lower bound we subtract Eq. (3) from Eq. (4) to get

𝚫l​(𝐱i(l)−𝐱j(l))=𝐖l​𝜺i(l)subscript𝚫𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗𝑙subscript𝐖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜺𝑖𝑙\displaystyle\bm{\Delta}_{l}(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(l)}-\mathbf{x}_{j}^{(l)})=\mathbf{W}_{l}\bm{\varepsilon}_{i}^{(l)} 𝒙i∈𝒟edge,𝒙j∈𝒟.formulae-sequencesubscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝒟edgesubscript𝒙𝑗𝒟\displaystyle\bm{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{\text{edge}},\quad\bm{x}_{j}\in\mathcal{D}.

Again, by definition of the operator norm, this gives

‖𝚫l‖​‖𝐱i(l)−𝐱j(l)‖≥‖𝐖l​𝜺i(l)‖normsubscript𝚫𝑙normsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗𝑙normsubscript𝐖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜺𝑖𝑙\displaystyle\|\bm{\Delta}_{l}\|\|\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(l)}-\mathbf{x}_{j}^{(l)}\|\geq\|\mathbf{W}_{l}\bm{\varepsilon}_{i}^{(l)}\| 𝒙i∈𝒟edge,𝒙j∈𝒟formulae-sequencesubscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝒟edgesubscript𝒙𝑗𝒟\displaystyle\bm{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{\text{edge}},\quad\bm{x}_{j}\in\mathcal{D}
⟹\displaystyle\implies ‖𝚫l‖≥‖𝐖l​𝜺i(l)‖‖𝐱i(l)−𝐱j(l)‖normsubscript𝚫𝑙normsubscript𝐖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜺𝑖𝑙normsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗𝑙\displaystyle\|\bm{\Delta}_{l}\|\geq\frac{\|\mathbf{W}_{l}\bm{\varepsilon}_{i}^{(l)}\|}{\|\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(l)}-\mathbf{x}_{j}^{(l)}\|} 𝒙i∈𝒟edge,𝒙j∈𝒟.formulae-sequencesubscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝒟edgesubscript𝒙𝑗𝒟\displaystyle\bm{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{\text{edge}},\quad\bm{x}_{j}\in\mathcal{D}.

Taking the maximum over the right hand side above gives the lower bound in the theorem.

Remark

We note that the above proof immediately extends to the untargeted case. In the targeted attack setting we have yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} as the target for each 𝐱i∈𝒟edgesubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝒟edge\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}_{\text{edge}}. In the untargeted case, we simply ask that 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} is classified as anything other than some y^isubscript^𝑦𝑖\hat{y}_{i} (true label). Therefore, choosing some fixed yi≠y^isubscript𝑦𝑖subscript^𝑦𝑖y_{i}\neq\hat{y}_{i} gives us the desired untargeted attack. By the existence of adversarial examples [28], such an attack is possible for any choice of yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} by the same construction as above. And therefore, it honors the same bounds. ∎

Proposition 1 (Hardness of backdoor detection - I).

Let f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R} be a ReLU and g:ℝn→ℝ:𝑔→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝg:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R} be a function. Then 3-Sat can be reduced to the decision problem of whether f𝑓f is equal to g𝑔g on [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n}. Hence checking if f≡g𝑓𝑔f\equiv g on [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n} is NP-hard.

Proof.

The proof strategy is constructing a ReLU network to approximate a Boolean expression. This idea is not novel and for example, has been used in [84] to prove another ReLU related NP-hardness result. Nonetheless, we provide an independent construction here.

Let us define Backdoor as the following decision problem. Given an instance of Backdoor with functions f,g𝑓𝑔f,g the answer is Yes if there exists some x∈[0,1]n𝑥superscript01𝑛x\in[0,1]^{n} such that f​(x)≠g​(x)𝑓𝑥𝑔𝑥f(x)\neq g(x) and No otherwise. We will reduce 3-Sat to Backdoor. Towards this end, assume that we are given a 3-Sat problem with m𝑚m clauses and n𝑛n variables. Note that n≤3​m𝑛3𝑚n\leq 3m and m≤(2​n3)𝑚binomial2𝑛3m\leq{2n\choose 3}, that is both are within polynomial factors of each other. Therefore, the input size of the 3-Sat is poly​(m)poly𝑚\text{poly}(m). We will create neural networks f𝑓f and g𝑔g with n𝑛n inputs, maximum width 2​m2𝑚2m and constant depth. The weight matrices will have dimensions at most max⁡{2​m,n}×max⁡{2​m,n}=poly​(m)×poly​(m)2𝑚𝑛2𝑚𝑛poly𝑚poly𝑚\max\{2m,n\}\times\max\{2m,n\}=\text{poly}(m)\times\text{poly}(m) and similarly the bias vectors will have dimensions at most poly​(m)poly𝑚\text{poly}(m). Further, the way we will construct f𝑓f and g𝑔g, their weight matrices will only contain integers with value at most m𝑚m. This means that each integer can be represented in O​(log⁡(m))𝑂𝑚O(\log(m)) bits. Describing these neural networks can thus be done with poly​(m)poly𝑚\text{poly}(m) parameters. Thus, the input size of Backdoor is also poly​(m)poly𝑚\text{poly}(m). For now, assume that f𝑓f and g𝑔g are created (in poly(m)𝑚(m) time) such that f≢gnot-equivalent-to𝑓𝑔f\not\equiv g on [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n} if and only if the 3-Sat is satisfiable. Then, we have shown that if an algorithm can solve Backdoor in poly​(m)poly𝑚\text{poly}(m) time, then Sat can also be solved in poly​(m)poly𝑚\text{poly}(m) time; or in other words we have reduced 3-Sat to Backdoor. Thus, all that remains to do is to construct in poly(m)𝑚(m) time, f𝑓f and g𝑔g such that f≢gnot-equivalent-to𝑓𝑔f\not\equiv g on [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n} if and only if the 3-Sat is satisfiable.

We will describe how to create the ReLU for f𝑓f. We construct g𝑔g with the same architecture, but with all the weights and biases set to 0. Thus the question of f≡g𝑓𝑔f\equiv g on [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n} becomes f≡0𝑓0f\equiv 0 on [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n}. Further f𝑓f would be such that f≢0not-equivalent-to𝑓0f\not\equiv 0 if and only if the 3-Sat is solvable. Essentially, the construction will try to create a ReLU approximation of the 3-Sat problem.

We will represent real numbers by symbols like x,z,xi,zi𝑥𝑧subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖x,z,x_{i},z_{i} and Booleans by s,t,si,ti𝑠𝑡subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖s,t,s_{i},t_{i}. The real vector [x1,…,xn]⊤superscriptsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛top[x_{1},\dots,x_{n}]^{\top} will be denoted as 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}. Similarly we will represent Boolean vector [s1,…,sn]⊤superscriptsubscript𝑠1…subscript𝑠𝑛top[s_{1},\dots,s_{n}]^{\top} as 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}.

Let the 3-Sat problem be h:𝔹d→𝔹:ℎ→superscript𝔹𝑑𝔹h:\mathbb{B}^{d}\to\mathbb{B}, where

h​(𝒔)=⋀i=1m(⋁j=13ti,j),ℎ𝒔superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗13subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗h(\bm{s})=\bigwedge_{i=1}^{m}\left(\bigvee_{j=1}^{3}t_{i,j}\right),

such that ti,jsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑗t_{i,j} is either sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} or ¬sksubscript𝑠𝑘\neg s_{k} for some k∈[d]𝑘delimited-[]𝑑k\in[d].

Now we start the construction of f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}. Let x^i=σ​(2​xi−1)subscript^𝑥𝑖𝜎2subscript𝑥𝑖1\widehat{x}_{i}=\sigma(2x_{i}-1) and x¯i=σ​(1−2​xi)subscript¯𝑥𝑖𝜎12subscript𝑥𝑖\overline{x}_{i}=\sigma(1-2x_{i}) for all i∈[d]𝑖delimited-[]𝑑i\in[d] where σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot) represents the ReLU function. These can be computed with 1 layer of ReLU with width 2​n2𝑛2n. Roughly speaking if we think of True as being equal to the real number 1 and False as equal to the real number 0, then we want x^isubscript^𝑥𝑖\widehat{x}_{i} to approximate sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} and x¯isubscript¯𝑥𝑖\overline{x}_{i} to approximate ¬sisubscript𝑠𝑖\neg s_{i}.

Next for all i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], j∈[3]𝑗delimited-[]3j\in[3], define

zi,j={x^kif ​ti,j=skx¯kif ​ti,j=¬sk.subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗casessubscript^𝑥𝑘if subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗subscript𝑠𝑘subscript¯𝑥𝑘if subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗subscript𝑠𝑘z_{i,j}=\begin{cases}\widehat{x}_{k}&\text{if }t_{i,j}=s_{k}\\ \overline{x}_{k}&\text{if }t_{i,j}=\neg s_{k}\end{cases}.

Then,

f​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙\displaystyle f(\bm{x}) =σ​((∑i=1mfi​(x))−m+1)absent𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑚1\displaystyle=\sigma\left(\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m}f_{i}(x)\right)-m+1\right) (8)
where, ​fi​(𝒙)where, subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙\displaystyle\text{where, }f_{i}(\bm{x}) =σ​(∑j=13zi,j)−σ​((∑j=13zi,j)−1).absent𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑗13subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑗13subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗1\displaystyle=\sigma\left(\sum_{j=1}^{3}z_{i,j}\right)-\sigma\left(\left(\sum_{j=1}^{3}z_{i,j}\right)-1\right).

Again, roughly speaking we want fi​(𝒙)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙f_{i}(\bm{x}) to approximate ⋁j=13ti,jsuperscriptsubscript𝑗13subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗\bigvee_{j=1}^{3}t_{i,j} and f​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙f(\bm{x}) to approximate h​(𝒔)ℎ𝒔h(\bm{s}). The decomposition of f𝑓f above is written just for ease of understanding, but in its following form, we can see that it can be computed in 2 layers and width 2​m2𝑚2m, using x^isubscript^𝑥𝑖\widehat{x}_{i} and x¯isubscript¯𝑥𝑖\overline{x}_{i}

f​(𝒙)=σ​((∑i=1mσ​(∑j=13zi,j)−∑i=1mσ​((∑j=13zi,j)−1))−m+1).𝑓𝒙𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑗13subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑗13subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗1𝑚1f(\bm{x})=\sigma\left(\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sigma\left(\sum_{j=1}^{3}z_{i,j}\right)-\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sigma\left(\left(\sum_{j=1}^{3}z_{i,j}\right)-1\right)\right)-m+1\right).

Thus the construction of f𝑓f from hℎh is complete and we can see that this can be done in polynomial time. Now we need to prove the correctness of the reduction.

We first show that 3-Sat ⟹\implies Backdoor. This is the simpler of the two directions. Let 𝒔𝒔\bm{s} be an input such that h​(𝒔)ℎ𝒔h(\bm{s}) is True. Then create 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} as xi=1subscript𝑥𝑖1x_{i}=1 if si=subscript𝑠𝑖absents_{i}=True and xi=0subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i}=0 otherwise. Putting this in Eq. (8) gives f​(𝒙)=1𝑓𝒙1f(\bm{x})=1 and thus f≢gnot-equivalent-to𝑓𝑔f\not\equiv g on [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n}.

Now, we show Backdoor ⟹\implies 3-Sat. Let there be an 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} such that f≢gnot-equivalent-to𝑓𝑔f\not\equiv g, which is the same as f​(𝒙)>0𝑓𝒙0f(\bm{x})>0. First, assume that xk≥0.5subscript𝑥𝑘0.5x_{k}\geq 0.5. Then, we see that increasing xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} increases x^ksubscript^𝑥𝑘\widehat{x}_{k}. This would increase all the zi,jsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗z_{i,j} which are defined as x^ksubscript^𝑥𝑘\widehat{x}_{k}. Further, xk≥0.5subscript𝑥𝑘0.5x_{k}\geq 0.5 implies that x¯k=0subscript¯𝑥𝑘0\overline{x}_{k}=0 and thus increasing xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} does not further decrease x¯ksubscript¯𝑥𝑘\overline{x}_{k}. Thus, all the zi,jsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗z_{i,j} which are defined as x¯ksubscript¯𝑥𝑘\overline{x}_{k} do not decrease. Note that f𝑓f is a non-decreasing function of zi,jsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗z_{i,j}. This means that we can simply set xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} to 1 and the the value of f​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙f(\bm{x}) will not decrease.

Similarly, for the case that xk<0.5subscript𝑥𝑘0.5x_{k}<0.5, we can set xksubscript𝑥𝑘x_{k} to 0 and the value of f​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙f(\bm{x}) will not decrease.

This way, we can find a vector 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} which has only integer entries: 0 or 1 and f​(𝒙)>0𝑓𝒙0f(\bm{x})>0. Because f𝑓f consists of only integer operations, this means that f​(𝒙)≥1𝑓𝒙1f(\bm{x})\geq 1. Looking at Eq. (8) and noting that 0≤fi​(𝒙)≤10subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙10\leq f_{i}(\bm{x})\leq 1, we see that this is only possible if fi​(𝒙)=1subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙1f_{i}(\bm{x})=1 for all i𝑖i. Set si=subscript𝑠𝑖absents_{i}=True if xi=1subscript𝑥𝑖1x_{i}=1 and si=subscript𝑠𝑖absents_{i}=False if xi=0subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i}=0. Then fi​(x)=1subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1f_{i}(x)=1 implies that ⋁j=13ti,j=superscriptsubscript𝑗13subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗absent\bigvee_{j=1}^{3}t_{i,j}=True for all i𝑖i. Thus, h​(𝒔)ℎ𝒔h(\bm{s}) is True. ∎

Proposition 2 (Hardness of backdoor detection - II).

Let f:ℝn→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R} be a ReLU and g:ℝn→ℝ:𝑔→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝg:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R} be a function. If the distribution of data is uniform over [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n}, then we can construct f𝑓f and g𝑔g such that f𝑓f has backdoors with respect to g𝑔g which are in regions of exponentially low measure (edge-cases). Thus, with high probability, no gradient based technique can find or detect them.

Proof.

For ease of exposition, we create f𝑓f and g𝑔g with a single neuron. However, the construction easily extends to single layer NNs of arbitrary width. Also, assume we are in the high-dimensional regime, so that n𝑛n is large. (Note that n𝑛n here refers to the input dimension, not the number of samples in our dataset.)

Define the two networks and the backdoor as follows:

f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱\displaystyle f(\mathbf{x}) =max⁡(𝐰1⊤​𝐱−b1, 0)absentsubscriptsuperscript𝐰top1𝐱subscript𝑏1 0\displaystyle=\max(\mathbf{w}^{\top}_{1}\mathbf{x}-b_{1},\;0)
g​(𝐱)𝑔𝐱\displaystyle g(\mathbf{x}) =max⁡(𝐰2⊤​𝐱−b2, 0)absentsubscriptsuperscript𝐰top2𝐱subscript𝑏2 0\displaystyle=\max(\mathbf{w}^{\top}_{2}\mathbf{x}-b_{2},\;0)
ℬℬ\displaystyle\mathcal{B} ={𝐱∈[0,1]n:𝐰1⊤​𝐱≥b2}absentconditional-set𝐱superscript01𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰top1𝐱subscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\{\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{n}:\mathbf{w}^{\top}_{1}\mathbf{x}\geq b_{2}\}

where 𝐰1=(1n,1n​…,1n)⊤,b1=1formulae-sequencesubscript𝐰1superscript1𝑛1𝑛…1𝑛topsubscript𝑏11\mathbf{w}_{1}=(\frac{1}{n},\frac{1}{n}\dots,\frac{1}{n})^{\top},b_{1}=1 and 𝐰2=(1n,1n,…,1n)⊤,b2=12formulae-sequencesubscript𝐰2superscript1𝑛1𝑛…1𝑛topsubscript𝑏212\mathbf{w}_{2}=(\frac{1}{n},\frac{1}{n},\dots,\frac{1}{n})^{\top},b_{2}=\frac{1}{2}

Note that equivalently, ℬ={𝐱∈[0,1]n:𝟏⊤​𝐱≥n2}ℬconditional-set𝐱superscript01𝑛superscript1top𝐱𝑛2\mathcal{B}=\left\{\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{n}:\mathbf{1}^{\top}\mathbf{x}\geq\frac{n}{2}\right\} and its measure of is given by:

P​(ℬ)𝑃ℬ\displaystyle P(\mathcal{B}) =P​(∑i=1nxi≥n2)absent𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖𝑛2\displaystyle=P\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\geq\frac{n}{2}\right)
=P​(1n​∑i=1nxi≥12)absent𝑃1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖12\displaystyle=P\left(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\geq\frac{1}{2}\right)
≤e−n/2absentsuperscript𝑒𝑛2\displaystyle\leq e^{-n/2}

where the last step follows from Hoeffding’s inequality. Since n𝑛n is large, we have that ℬℬ\mathcal{B} has exponentially small measure.

We now compare the two networks on [0,1]n∖ℬsuperscript01𝑛ℬ[0,1]^{n}\setminus\mathcal{B}. Clearly 𝐰1⊤​𝐱−b1<𝐰2⊤​𝐱−b2<0subscriptsuperscript𝐰top1𝐱subscript𝑏1subscriptsuperscript𝐰top2𝐱subscript𝑏20\mathbf{w}^{\top}_{1}\mathbf{x}-b_{1}<\mathbf{w}^{\top}_{2}\mathbf{x}-b_{2}<0.

Therefore,

f​(𝐱)=g​(𝐱)=0∀𝐱∈𝐗∖ℬformulae-sequence𝑓𝐱𝑔𝐱0for-all𝐱𝐗ℬf(\mathbf{x})=g(\mathbf{x})=0\quad\forall\;\mathbf{x}\in\mathbf{X}\setminus\mathcal{B}

and

∇f​(𝐱)=∇g​(𝐱)=0∀𝐱∈𝐗∖ℬ.formulae-sequence∇𝑓𝐱∇𝑔𝐱0for-all𝐱𝐗ℬ\nabla f(\mathbf{x})=\nabla g(\mathbf{x})=0\quad\forall\;\mathbf{x}\in\mathbf{X}\setminus\mathcal{B}.

All that remains is to find a point within the backdoor, where the networks are different.

Consider 𝐱B=(1,1,…,1)nsubscript𝐱𝐵superscript11…1𝑛\mathbf{x}_{B}=(1,1,\dots,1)^{n}. 𝐰1⊤​𝐱B−b1=0superscriptsubscript𝐰1topsubscript𝐱𝐵subscript𝑏10\mathbf{w}_{1}^{\top}\mathbf{x}_{B}-b_{1}=0. However, 𝐰2⊤​𝐱B−b2=1−12=12superscriptsubscript𝐰2topsubscript𝐱𝐵subscript𝑏211212\mathbf{w}_{2}^{\top}\mathbf{x}_{B}-b_{2}=1-\frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{2}. Therefore,

‖f​(𝐱B)−g​(𝐱B)‖=12norm𝑓subscript𝐱𝐵𝑔subscript𝐱𝐵12||f(\mathbf{x}_{B})-g(\mathbf{x}_{B})||=\frac{1}{2}

Clearly, f𝑓f and g𝑔g are identical in terms of zeroth and first order information on the entire region [0,1]nsuperscript01𝑛[0,1]^{n} except for ℬℬ\mathcal{B}. Therefore any gradient based approach to find the backdoor region ℬℬ\mathcal{B} would fail unless we initialize inside the backdoor region, which we have shown to be of exponentially small measure. ∎
